718042f-a.text:
Canal Street (right), north side, from Hudson to Varick Streets, and Watts Street (left), north side, east from Hudson. The Watts Stree buildings will be demolished in the mid 1920's for the Holland Tunnel Plaza.
1908.
Brown Brothers.
NEeGG ~ 376S
718042f-a.folder: Canal Street & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY

720511f-a.text:
Hudson Street (right), east side, south from Canal Streets Also shown is Canal Street (left), south side, east from Hudson Street, showing at the corner (S.E.) Salmon's Pharmacy with the New York Central Railroad tracks (Hudson Street, right) passing its door. Buildings shown at this corner, were razed in approximately 1928 and on their site was erected the 12-story Green Terminal Building. On Canal Street, extending to Varick Street (where street car is visible) is now also the exit of the Holland Tunnel.
1908.
Brown Brothers.
720511f-a.folder: Hudson Street & Canal Street, Manhattan, NY

718044f-a.text:
(1)
461 to 481 Canal Street, north side, east of, adjoining, and at
the east corner of Hudson Street.
October 10, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same part of the block, looking northwest, after the demolition of the old buildings.
February 12, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

718046f-a.text:
Canal Street, south side, west from Hudson (left), to Watts (right) Streets, showing a row of old buildings occupying this block front and which subsequently will be replaced by a 12 story loft structure (prior to 1932). The structure bearing the Miller Tompkins & Co. signs is to be reconstructed according to the N.Y. times of October 20, 1937 and occupied by the firm of Magnus, Mabee & Reynard Inc. of 257 Pearl Street, dealers in essential oils. It will have translucent glass fronts on both its Desbrosses (No. 16) and Watts (No. 119-21) Street sides. Note on the latter thoroughfare, the Ninth
Avenue "El" running on Greenwich Street.
September 27, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
718046f-a.folder: Canal Street & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY

720501f-b.text:
(1)
219 to 259 Hudson Street, west side, at, adjoining, and north of Canal Street, N. W. corner. No. 241, the white house adjoining the vacant lot on the north is a brick-faced frame, as are the three-story building at No.249 and the 4-story building adjoining
it on the north, No. 253.
September 27, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, and north to Spring Street, nearly six years later. A filling station has, since 1931, replaced Nos. 219,221,223, at the corner of Canal Street, Nos. 261, 263, 265, not shown in the
first picture, are also brick-faced frame houses.
June 7, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A detail of No. 1, showing the buildings that are razed in No. 2.
June 30, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

720504f-a.text:
Hudson Street, east side, at Canal Street. In the right foreground is a sentry box used by the railroad flagman. at this point the railroad tracks turn off Canal Street and down Hudson.
December 20, 1932,
P. L. Sperr.
720504f-a.folder: Hudson Street & Canal Street, Manhattan, NY

720514f-a.text:
259 to 275 Hudson Street, west side, between Canal and Spring Streets. Nos. 261-265, the three 3-story houses in the center of the picture are frame, faced with brick; the first being a brick structure. No. 271, the 5-story tenement just north of the last frame house will be demolished (1937).  1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 562.
720514f-a.folder: Hudson Street & Canal Street, Manhattan, NY

720505f.text:
247-249, 251-253 Hudson Street, west side, north of Canal Street, a rear view across the site of 22-26 Renwick Street, which were
demolished around 1930.
About 1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection,Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 577.
720505f.folder: Hudson Street & Canal Street, Manhattan, NY

720510f-a.text:
253, 249, 245, 241 Hudson Street, west side, north of Canal Street and opposite the western end of Broome Street. No. 243-245, adjoining the light colored house next to the vacant lot, is a solid brick building, but the other three houses are frame with
brick facings.
About 1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 56l.
720510f-a.folder: Hudson Street & Canal Street, Manhattan, NY

720521f-b.text:
(1) Hudson Street, west side, from Canal Street to Vandam, across east side from Canal to Spring. At the left, a freight train on Canal Street is shown turning south into Hudson Street.

(2) The same, and north of Vandam Street in the background, four yeaars later. The new building partially shown at the right is at the NE corner of Broome Street. June 7, 1933.

P. L. Sperr
No reproductions.

718049f-a.text:
Canal Street, north side, west from Hudson (right) to Renwick (left) Streets. The photographer is viewing northwestward and includes at the right an extensive view up Hudson Street. Views 2 and 3 are of the same locale,though the latter veers eastward to show the westerly portion of the Holland Tunnel Plaza. The entrance to same adjoins the Board of Transportation Building, (Chevrolet sign). This structure occupies the entire easterly frontage of Hudson Street from Broome to Dominick Streets.
View 1: June 3, 1933
Views 2-3 July 26, 1935
P . L. Sperr
718049f-a.folder: Canal Street & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY

718048f-b.text:

495-501 Canal Street, north side, between Hudson and Renwick Streets. as seen from across Watts Street. Also shown is Renwick Street,(clearance) at the N.E. corner of Canal Street.

720506f-a.text:
Hudson Street, west side, north of Canal Street. Also shown are Nos. 15-21 Renwick Street, (Across clearance), at and adjoining the N.W. corner
of Canal Street.
July 27. 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
720506f-a.folder: Hudson Street & Canal Street, Manhattan, NY

720520f-a.text:
Hudson Street, west side, north from Canal (left) to Vandam (center) Streets, as seen from Canal (immediate foreground) Street. The large structure of which only the lower floors appear is the Board of Transportation Building and is at the N.E. corner of Hudson and Broome Streets. To the right of same (not shown) is the entrance to the Holland Tunnel.
June 11, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.
720520f-a.folder: Hudson Street & Canal Street, Manhattan, NY

720503f-a.text:

Manhattan Highways Comm.  January 26th,1937

718043f-a.text:
Canal Street, north side, from Hudson to Varick Streets, inclusive, looking at Varick Street across the cleared triangular block where the Holland Plaza Building will rise. This is the block shown in
Brown Brothers' 1908 view.
February 25, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
